field_edited_text.value:
VOL. XXVIII, No 58
OF STUDENT
EXTENSION
COUNCIL'S POWERS
APPROVED
Faculty Committee and Dean Ames
Pass Favorably on Resolution
Adopted by Council in April

Extension of the powers of the
Student Council was approved at
a meeting of the Faculty Committee on Student Affairs which was
held last week. The committee,
which consists of Drs. French, Latane and Swartz, was called for the
purpose of acting on a resolution
passed by the Student Council in
April. Thomas P. Magill, president-elect of the Student Council,
and Daniel Klein-, secretary, conferred with the committee concerning the present conditions and future policy of the Student Council.
Dean Ames has- heartily approved of the resolution which has
broadened the Student Council's
powers so as to include supervision
of conduct in all places where individuals Or groups are gathered
as Hopkins students. In the second
article the Council has resolved to
make the honor system more effective. The third and last article
empowers the Student Council to
exercise jurisdiction over the second floor of the barn, excepting
the Y. M. C. A. and Athletic offices.
Resolutions Adopted

The new resolution widening the
field of the Student Council's jurisdiction is as follows:
1. The Student Council shall be
empowered to promote good order
in undergraduate affairs and shall
exercise primary jurisdiction in
questions of conduct on the part of
any undergraduate or group of undergraduates which shall be deemed
unbecoming a gentleman or prejudicial to the honor of the university.
2. The Council Stall take measures to make the Johns Hopkins
honor system effective in examinations, quizzes and student exercises
of all sorts.
3. The Council shall exercise
jurisdiction over the second floor
of the "Barn" exclusive of the Y.
M. C. A. and Athletic offices.
This step of the Student Council
has been greeted with universal approval both by the faculty and student body. It is regarded as a move
to protect the name of the university from undeserved criticism and
to have some check on Hopkins affairs off the campus.
WILLISON ELECTED HEAD OF
DEBATING COUNCIL
At a meeting of the Debating
Council held last Thursday the officers and delegates for the ensuing
year were elected. The result follows: President, Paul Willison;
secretary-treasurer, Reno Harp.
The delegates from the various
classes are: Sophomore, Alfred L.
Edgerter ; Junior, Reno Harp and
Allan L. Grafflin ; Senior, Paul
Willison, Daniel Klein and Elmer
Mylander.
The Council has decided to tq
to revive interest in debating at
Hopkins by making a heavier schedule and by making the debates more
of social functions than has been
the custom. The debates were popular and well supported until very
recently, so the Council will try to
bring them back to their former
status in the eyes- of the students. -

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 20, 1924

0. D. K. RE-ELECTS
TURNBULL PRESIDENT
Douglas C. Turnbull, Jr.,
'24, was re-elected President
of the Beta Circle !of the
Omicron Delta Kappa Honorary Society at a meeting
held Sunday afternoon. Although Turnbull has served
one year as President, his reelection was thought advisable in. view of the fact that
he will return to- the University next year for his
fourth year, and the other
men eligible for the position
have been only recently initiated. The other officers
elected were: Vice-President, Thomas P. Magill,'25;
Secretary, R. Carmichael
Tilghman, '25,. and Treasurer, Earl Donaldson,'25.
CLASS REUNIONS DURING
JUNE WEEK PLANNED
BY GRADUATES
Old-timers Expected to Attend Undergraduate Celebration in Force.
Novel Events Planned

At least four classes are to have
reunions during June Week, according to B. P. Thomas, of the
executive committee, who is in
charge of getting alumni back for
the various affairs. The class of
1923 will probably have the largest
representation as seventy-five of
last year's graduates intend to return to the campus. Thomas Landy, chairman of 1923 June Week,
has been working quietly for several months and a majority of the
class is expected to be on hand
when the curtain goes up for the
first affair.
The classes of 1919 and 1914 are
planning reunions and prominent
members of the classes of 1909 and
1904 are endeavoring to get their
members back in the fold. The
class of 1899, of which Dr. J. C.
French is a member, is planning a
reunion to last several days. If
these classes all return, five, ten, fifteen, twenty and twenty-five year
reunions will be held and the June
Week affairs will be attended by
a large number of Hopkins graduates.
Graduates Will Be Welcomed

Several special features have
been arranged for the old boys.
Booths will be specially constructed
for them at the dances and it is
probable that arrangements will be
made so that out-of-town alumni
may be housed in the Memorial
Dormitory. Representatives from
these classes will be asked to take
a part in the Class Day exercises
and in other functions.
The committee is spending a
large amount of time makink plans
for the cabaret in the Botanical
Gardens, to be held simultanecusly
with the Last Cotillon and the Student Activities dance. A negro orchestra has been secured to furnish
the music between numbers and it
is probable that a platform for
dances will be constructed. It is
thought that dancing to dreamy
melodies by the light of the moon
and dim .Japanese lanterns will
prove very attractive.. Refreshments will be served throughout
the evening.

CORONA

Hostilities between Hopkins and
the Naval Academy will be renewed
tomorrow in the realm of tennis.
The Black and Blue racqueters,
smarting under the defeat administered to the junior netmen at the
hands of the Middy second string
men, will attempt to even up matters with the sailors.
The Hopkins second team was
defeated by the Middies 4 to 0 in a
match played at Annapolis last
Thursday. Rain, which called an
end to the match, was in all probability the reason for the gooseegg score. The downpour started
while the doubles were being played
and the Black and Blue players
were in the advantage.
Lowrey of Navy, showed the
best form of any of the participants in the match and Goldstein
exhibited the best playing for
Hopkins.

play Delaware here Saturday, but
on account of the examinations to
be held on that day the match may
be called off or postponed. The

ENGINEERS VISIT NATIONAL
BUREAU OF STANDARDS
Last Thursday the seniors of the
civil, mechanical and electrical engineering departments were conducted through the National Bureau of Standards at Washington
by four members of the engineering faculty at Hopkins. Those in
charge of the party were Professors William R. Kouvenhouven,
Joseph T. Thompson, Frederick W.
Lee and H. C. Waterfall.
The majority of the party drove
over to Washington in automobiles
and spent the evening there. Starting on their tour through the plant
at ten in the morning the students
remained there until four in the
afternoon, taking off only a half
hour for lunch. Despite this long
period spent in the plant, the students say they did not see even a
quarter of the numerous types of
apparatus. As a souvenir of the trip
the students brought back a partially completed silk stocking, feminine gender, made on a stocking
machine which was being tested at
the bureau.

For
GENERAL
USE

Sold by
STATIONERS, DRUG AND
DEPARTMENT STORES

in

-1
the interest ofElectrical Development by
an Institution that will
be helped by whatever helps the
Industry.

Your college training is in truth a capital. Its value
is not fixed, but depends on the way you invest it.
Some men demand a quick return — a high percentage of profit. Others look more to the solidity
of the investment.
The man of speculative mind may stake all on the
lure of a high starting salary, without a thought to
the company which gives it or where this may lead
him in ten years. True, his opportunism may reap
exceptional profit; or else a loss.
The man who knows that great things develop
slowly will be content with six months' progress in
six months' time—provided he is investing that
time in a company which offers him a future.
You who are about to invest, satisfy yourself that
the security you are getting is gilt-edged.

Yesterday the R. 0. T. C. Unit
held the final review for the year.
The last formation held in honor
of Major General Charles H. Muir,
Chief of the Third Corp Area, U.
S. Army, and President Frank J.
Goodnow, took place at 4:15 P. M.
on the upper quadrangle. The order of the exercises was as follows:
1. Review for the faculty and
guests.
2. Addresses by Major General
Muir and President Goodnow.
-3. Presentation of cups and
medals by Dr. Goodnow.
4. Competition for the bc,4
drilled private.
5. Awarding of commissions in
the U. S. Army Reserve Corps by
Major General Muir.

General Muir expressed his
pleasure at seeing the high grade
of proficiency which the Cadet
boys had attained in their drilling.
He said that the twenty-two men
who had been awarded commiss?,)ns
as second lieutenants in the U. S.
Reserve Corp would be valuable
additions to that organization. His
address showed him to be strongly
in favor of R. 0. T. C. training.
President Goodnow reviewed the
past record of the Hopkin's Unit
and expressed the belief that, undkr Major Horsington, the Unit
would not fall below the high level
of its former performances.

OUR MEN'S SHOP

It sums up like this:

DR. HESS TO SPEAK BEFORE
FIELD CLUB
At its final session of the year tomorrow the Naturalists' Field Club
will hear Dr. Walter N. Hess,
Johnston scholar, talk on "The
Nesting Habits of Stickleback
Fishes." Dr. Hess has for some
time been carrying on research
work at Hopkins. Mr. Archie D.
Shaftesbury, president of the
club, will deliver a lecture on
"Parasites of the Honey Bee."
There is not much concerning the honey bee that Mr.
Shaftesbury does not know, having
devoted several years to the study
of that insect.
Election of next year's officers
will be held at the same meeting,
when a president and. secretary will
be chosen. This meeting of the Naturalists'
Club will take place
in Room 10, Gilman Hall, at 3 P.

field_edited_text.processed:
VOL. XXVIII, No 58
OF STUDENT
EXTENSION
COUNCIL'S POWERS
APPROVED
Faculty Committee and Dean Ames
Pass Favorably on Resolution
Adopted by Council in April

Extension of the powers of the
Student Council was approved at
a meeting of the Faculty Committee on Student Affairs which was
held last week. The committee,
which consists of Drs. French, Latane and Swartz, was called for the
purpose of acting on a resolution
passed by the Student Council in
April. Thomas P. Magill, president-elect of the Student Council,
and Daniel Klein-, secretary, conferred with the committee concerning the present conditions and future policy of the Student Council.
Dean Ames has- heartily approved of the resolution which has
broadened the Student Council's
powers so as to include supervision
of conduct in all places where individuals Or groups are gathered
as Hopkins students. In the second
article the Council has resolved to
make the honor system more effective. The third and last article
empowers the Student Council to
exercise jurisdiction over the second floor of the barn, excepting
the Y. M. C. A. and Athletic offices.
Resolutions Adopted

The new resolution widening the
field of the Student Council's jurisdiction is as follows:
1. The Student Council shall be
empowered to promote good order
in undergraduate affairs and shall
exercise primary jurisdiction in
questions of conduct on the part of
any undergraduate or group of undergraduates which shall be deemed
unbecoming a gentleman or prejudicial to the honor of the university.
2. The Council Stall take measures to make the Johns Hopkins
honor system effective in examinations, quizzes and student exercises
of all sorts.
3. The Council shall exercise
jurisdiction over the second floor
of the "Barn" exclusive of the Y.
M. C. A. and Athletic offices.
This step of the Student Council
has been greeted with universal approval both by the faculty and student body. It is regarded as a move
to protect the name of the university from undeserved criticism and
to have some check on Hopkins affairs off the campus.
WILLISON ELECTED HEAD OF
DEBATING COUNCIL
At a meeting of the Debating
Council held last Thursday the officers and delegates for the ensuing
year were elected. The result follows: President, Paul Willison;
secretary-treasurer, Reno Harp.
The delegates from the various
classes are: Sophomore, Alfred L.
Edgerter ; Junior, Reno Harp and
Allan L. Grafflin ; Senior, Paul
Willison, Daniel Klein and Elmer
Mylander.
The Council has decided to tq
to revive interest in debating at
Hopkins by making a heavier schedule and by making the debates more
of social functions than has been
the custom. The debates were popular and well supported until very
recently, so the Council will try to
bring them back to their former
status in the eyes- of the students. -

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 20, 1924

0. D. K. RE-ELECTS
TURNBULL PRESIDENT
Douglas C. Turnbull, Jr.,
'24, was re-elected President
of the Beta Circle !of the
Omicron Delta Kappa Honorary Society at a meeting
held Sunday afternoon. Although Turnbull has served
one year as President, his reelection was thought advisable in. view of the fact that
he will return to- the University next year for his
fourth year, and the other
men eligible for the position
have been only recently initiated. The other officers
elected were: Vice-President, Thomas P. Magill,'25;
Secretary, R. Carmichael
Tilghman, '25,. and Treasurer, Earl Donaldson,'25.
CLASS REUNIONS DURING
JUNE WEEK PLANNED
BY GRADUATES
Old-timers Expected to Attend Undergraduate Celebration in Force.
Novel Events Planned

At least four classes are to have
reunions during June Week, according to B. P. Thomas, of the
executive committee, who is in
charge of getting alumni back for
the various affairs. The class of
1923 will probably have the largest
representation as seventy-five of
last year's graduates intend to return to the campus. Thomas Landy, chairman of 1923 June Week,
has been working quietly for several months and a majority of the
class is expected to be on hand
when the curtain goes up for the
first affair.
The classes of 1919 and 1914 are
planning reunions and prominent
members of the classes of 1909 and
1904 are endeavoring to get their
members back in the fold. The
class of 1899, of which Dr. J. C.
French is a member, is planning a
reunion to last several days. If
these classes all return, five, ten, fifteen, twenty and twenty-five year
reunions will be held and the June
Week affairs will be attended by
a large number of Hopkins graduates.
Graduates Will Be Welcomed

Several special features have
been arranged for the old boys.
Booths will be specially constructed
for them at the dances and it is
probable that arrangements will be
made so that out-of-town alumni
may be housed in the Memorial
Dormitory. Representatives from
these classes will be asked to take
a part in the Class Day exercises
and in other functions.
The committee is spending a
large amount of time makink plans
for the cabaret in the Botanical
Gardens, to be held simultanecusly
with the Last Cotillon and the Student Activities dance. A negro orchestra has been secured to furnish
the music between numbers and it
is probable that a platform for
dances will be constructed. It is
thought that dancing to dreamy
melodies by the light of the moon
and dim .Japanese lanterns will
prove very attractive.. Refreshments will be served throughout
the evening.

CORONA

Hostilities between Hopkins and
the Naval Academy will be renewed
tomorrow in the realm of tennis.
The Black and Blue racqueters,
smarting under the defeat administered to the junior netmen at the
hands of the Middy second string
men, will attempt to even up matters with the sailors.
The Hopkins second team was
defeated by the Middies 4 to 0 in a
match played at Annapolis last
Thursday. Rain, which called an
end to the match, was in all probability the reason for the gooseegg score. The downpour started
while the doubles were being played
and the Black and Blue players
were in the advantage.
Lowrey of Navy, showed the
best form of any of the participants in the match and Goldstein
exhibited the best playing for
Hopkins.
June Week Games Scheduled

The first team is scheduled to
play Delaware here Saturday, but
on account of the examinations to
be held on that day the match may
be called off or postponed. The

ENGINEERS VISIT NATIONAL
BUREAU OF STANDARDS
Last Thursday the seniors of the
civil, mechanical and electrical engineering departments were conducted through the National Bureau of Standards at Washington
by four members of the engineering faculty at Hopkins. Those in
charge of the party were Professors William R. Kouvenhouven,
Joseph T. Thompson, Frederick W.
Lee and H. C. Waterfall.
The majority of the party drove
over to Washington in automobiles
and spent the evening there. Starting on their tour through the plant
at ten in the morning the students
remained there until four in the
afternoon, taking off only a half
hour for lunch. Despite this long
period spent in the plant, the students say they did not see even a
quarter of the numerous types of
apparatus. As a souvenir of the trip
the students brought back a partially completed silk stocking, feminine gender, made on a stocking
machine which was being tested at
the bureau.

Your college training is in truth a capital. Its value
is not fixed, but depends on the way you invest it.
Some men demand a quick return — a high percentage of profit. Others look more to the solidity
of the investment.
The man of speculative mind may stake all on the
lure of a high starting salary, without a thought to
the company which gives it or where this may lead
him in ten years. True, his opportunism may reap
exceptional profit; or else a loss.
The man who knows that great things develop
slowly will be content with six months' progress in
six months' time—provided he is investing that
time in a company which offers him a future.
You who are about to invest, satisfy yourself that
the security you are getting is gilt-edged.

Yesterday the R. 0. T. C. Unit
held the final review for the year.
The last formation held in honor
of Major General Charles H. Muir,
Chief of the Third Corp Area, U.
S. Army, and President Frank J.
Goodnow, took place at 4:15 P. M.
on the upper quadrangle. The order of the exercises was as follows:
1. Review for the faculty and
guests.
2. Addresses by Major General
Muir and President Goodnow.
-3. Presentation of cups and
medals by Dr. Goodnow.
4. Competition for the bc,4
drilled private.
5. Awarding of commissions in
the U. S. Army Reserve Corps by
Major General Muir.

General Muir expressed his
pleasure at seeing the high grade
of proficiency which the Cadet
boys had attained in their drilling.
He said that the twenty-two men
who had been awarded commiss?,)ns
as second lieutenants in the U. S.
Reserve Corp would be valuable
additions to that organization. His
address showed him to be strongly
in favor of R. 0. T. C. training.
President Goodnow reviewed the
past record of the Hopkin's Unit
and expressed the belief that, undkr Major Horsington, the Unit
would not fall below the high level
of its former performances.

OUR MEN'S SHOP

It sums up like this:

DR. HESS TO SPEAK BEFORE
FIELD CLUB
At its final session of the year tomorrow the Naturalists' Field Club
will hear Dr. Walter N. Hess,
Johnston scholar, talk on "The
Nesting Habits of Stickleback
Fishes." Dr. Hess has for some
time been carrying on research
work at Hopkins. Mr. Archie D.
Shaftesbury, president of the
club, will deliver a lecture on
"Parasites of the Honey Bee."
There is not much concerning the honey bee that Mr.
Shaftesbury does not know, having
devoted several years to the study
of that insect.
Election of next year's officers
will be held at the same meeting,
when a president and. secretary will
be chosen. This meeting of the Naturalists'
Club will take place
in Room 10, Gilman Hall, at 3 P.
